# Legal Operating Procedure
## L-1 Legal License [bold]L-1-A[/bold] - Sophonts cannot practice law under normal circumstances without a Legal Licence and it is a per shift authorisation.
[bold]L-1-B[/bold] - Sophonts with Legal Licences must act ethically and zealously represent their client with all reasonable evidence in court.
[bold]L-1-C[/bold] - Detectives, lawyers, the Head of Personnel, the Head of Security, the Magistrate, and the CO all have automatic Legal Licenses.
[bold]L-1-D[/bold] - If Security has no available representatives, the Head of Security may grant a temporary legal license for the purpose of charging a sophont.
[bold]L-1-E[/bold] - Any crewmember that has passed the SPACE BAR exam with official documentation can apply for a legal license.
## L-2 Procedure for Charges [bold]L-2-A[/bold] - If Security wants to charge a sophont, they must perform pre-trial convention and then either resolve the charge with trial or arbitration.
[bold]L-2-B[/bold] - If a sophont wants to charge another sophont, the Magistrate must agree with the premise. Then a pre-trial convention and a trial to resolve the charge.
[bold]L-2-C[/bold] - If there is no Magistrate, the Head of Personnel, then the CO, will act as a replacement.
## L-3 Pre-trial Convention [bold]L-3-A[/bold] - The Magistrate must be informed of the prosecuting body, defending body, and all potential charges. The Magistrate will create a title for the case.
[bold]L-3-B[/bold] - The Magistrate will arrange a pre-trial convention with both representatives to observe them presenting each article of evidence one at a time. Each side can raise issues with each other's evidence. The Magistrate has full control of the oral debate and will keep procedures brief.
[bold]L-3-C[/bold] - The Magistrate will approve any evidence that is relevant and reasonably legally gathered, tabling it.
[bold]L-3-D[/bold] - If pre-trial is in two thirds agreement that there is sufficient evidence, the Magistrate will schedule a trial. If there is overwhelming evidence against the defendant or they confessed and do not wish to go to trial the Magistrate will instead schedule arbitration. Otherwise the Magistrate will arrange another pre-trial.
## L-4 Court Session [bold]L-4-A[/bold] - The Court will be scheduled and announced at least fifteen minutes in advance with a list of every defendant in the sequential order they are scheduled posted outside the Courtroom.
[bold]L-4-B[/bold] - Once the Court Session has started, The Magistrate will introduce themself. The Magistrate will introduce the next trial with its Title as well as a list of all charges. The Magistrate will allow the prosecution then the defence to give their statements. Then the Magistrate will provide concluding remarks regarding their final verdict and justification for their punishment. Then the Magistrate will move onto the next trial or adjourn court if there are none left.
[bold]L-4-C[/bold] - The Magistrate will ensure that all evidence presented was previously tabled in pre-trial and that no new evidence is presented.
[bold]L-4-D[/bold] - The Magistrate will ensure that the prosecution and defense’s statements stay relevant and last around two minutes each so that the trial will last no more than six minutes.
## L-5 Arbitration [bold]L-5-A[/bold] - The Magistrate will convene with the prosecution and the defence privately, defaulting the defendant’s guilt, determining the punishment. The Magistrate will arrange this as soon as possible. The defence and the prosecution will argue orally over circumstances that enhance or mitigate the punishments for the defendants charges. The Magistrate will give their punishment and the arbitration is adjourned.
[bold]L-5-B[/bold] - The Magistrate must keep an arbitration under four minutes.
## L-6 Citation [bold]L-6-A[/bold] - Any verdict and sentence will be recorded for future.
[bold]L-6-B[/bold] - All court record sentences or verdicts shall be named thusly: #(Case Number)x.(Volume number)x dd.mm.yy (Name of Prosecutor or Prosecuting body) v. (Name of Defendant of Defendant body) over (Most prominent charge): (Title and name of magistrate).
